message.content:
<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken()
<<<code>>>: 
```
import java.util.Scanner;
import java.io.File;
import java.io.FileNotFoundException;
import java.util.StringTokenizer;

public class Graph1 {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws FileNotFoundException {
        int linecount = 0, ec = 0;
        String nbin = null, cbin = null;
        int[][] data = new int[5][5]; // Initialize the data array
        String e = "e";
        System.out.println("Graph Coloring Algorithm Test\n");
        Scanner sc = new Scanner(System.in);
        System.out.print("Enter graph input file name: ");
        String newfile = sc.nextLine() + ".txt";
        File file = new File(newfile);
        Scanner scan = new Scanner(file);
        while ((scan.hasNext())) {
            StringTokenizer t = new StringTokenizer(scan.nextLine());
            if (t.nextToken().equals(e)) {
                ec++;
                nbin = t.nextToken(); // Convert the string token to integer
                cbin = t.nextToken(); // Convert the string token to integer
            }
            linecount++;
            data[Integer.parseInt(nbin)][Integer.parseInt(cbin)] = 1; // Store the adjacency matrix entry in the data array
        }
        for (int i = 0; i < 5; ++i)
            for (int j = 0; j < 5; ++j) {
                System.out.print(data[i][j]);
            }
    }
}
```

<<<explanation>>>: 
1. Initialize the `data` array with the desired size (in this case, 5x5).
2. Use `StringTokenizer` to tokenize each line of the input file.
3. Check if the first token is equal to "e" to identify the adjacency matrix entries.
4. Convert the string tokens to integers using `Integer.parseInt()` and store them in `nbin` and `cbin`.
5. Use the converted integers to access the corresponding indices in the `data` array and set the value to 1.
6. Print the `data` array to verify the adjacency matrix entries.
